text: [Music]
hi so I work for the UK government and um until 2012 this was the UK
government's website this was where as a UK citizen you would find information
out um and this is a tax credit calculator I think I'm going to use the
hand mic okay so um this is a tax credit calculator so a tax credit is an
incentive from the UK government to encourage certain behaviors like uh investing uh parenting um and uh it
gives you money off your tax bill so this uh calculator um allowed you to put
in information about your income and your behaviors um and work out how much uh how much your of a tax credit you
could get so as a UK citizen if you saw a mistake in this calculator um and you
wanted to you know let them know to correct it firstly you'd have to get in touch with direct gov so somewhere on
this page would be a contact uh contact Direct gov you'd get in touch with them and tell them about the mistake um and
that might be difficult but let's say that was all fine and you found the right person to talk to then they would
then have to contact the supplier of this website because the website was outsourced
what happened there okay um to an external supplier and uh to get that external
supplier to investigate uh whe as to whether the mistake you'd found was actually uh required a code change to
get them to investigate that would cost tens of thousands of euros and then if they did determine
that a code change was required uh it would then cost hundreds of thousands of Euros no matter how small the code
change was it would cost hundreds of thousands of euros and the estimate would be maybe 6 to 12 months and the
releases were Big Bang releases once a year so if you timed it badly it would probably take about 18 months for your
code fix to go in but honestly if it was a small change uh it probably wouldn't get done anyway because that's a lot of
money okay in 2012 we launched the gov.uk website and this is um another
tax calculator this is a child benefit tax calculator uh child benefit is money you get from the government uh for each
child you have but if you earn over a certain amount you have to pay tax on that benefit and this calculator allows
you to put in your income and the number of children and other facts and to find out how much tax you'd have to
pay and um earlier this year in January a member of the public found uh an error
in this tax calculator so I just want to point out that it's quite an edge case um it's in the scenario where you are
claiming Child Benefits so you have children under 18 uh you're also claiming a pension and you also earn
over 555,000 a year so it's quite an edge case it probably didn't affect anyone or very few people if so but
there was an error and somebody spotted it so on the 24th of January this year
well so he found the code on GitHub for this calculator uh on the 24th of January he made a code fix and raised a
poor request against that code um that was a Sunday uh on the
Monday the 25th of January um the team looked into that code fix talked to the
um tax team worked out that was in fact era uh it was merged on the 27th of
January and deployed on the 29th of January so that's quite a big change
from the way that the previous site used to work and how the UK government handled its code so I'm going to talk to
you now about how we got to that situation how we are coding in the open now what that looks like for us um and
where we're going next with it my name is Anna Shipman I am a technical architect um and I am also the
open source lead so how do we get here so this goes back
to 2010 when Marth Elaine Fox who was then the UK government's digital Champion was asked to do a report on D
gov which was the first website that I showed you but her report actually went further um and she looked at the whole
way that the UK government interacted with um UK citizens digitally and she made several recommendations and one of
them was the formation of a unit in government to work on this kind of thing specifically uh and that was the
government digital service that's who I work for the government digital service is the unit of government within the
cabinet office which is um in the center of the UK government and our job is to
change the way that government works to transform the interaction between the citizen and the state the first thing we
did was launch the gov.uk website which I've shown you um and the next thing we did was we
worked with eight departments eight different parts of government to transform um various services to make
them better for customers for customers for users for Citizens um uh the aim
being to make digital services so good that people prefer to use the online route rather than um the phone or face
to face or by letter um so by services so the gov.uk website is how you get
information a service is like an interaction with government maybe how you give government information or or
pay money or something like that um so I'll give you a couple of examples of services um that we transformed
so the first one I want to talk about is personalized license plates um you can't do this in the same way in Germany in
Germany you can pay some money and you can change some of the numbers and letters um on the license plate in the UK you can change the entire license
plate using numbers and letters to spell out words or names or something like that so this is one um where she's used
letters and numbers to spell out her name Jenny and uh if you sell your car um you
presumably you want to keep the license plate that you've personalized uh you don't want that to go with your car um so you have to apply to dvla the
driver and vehicle licensing authority to U get authorization to keep that license plate um and that service is
called um you know retain a license plate um before we worked on this uh you
had to fill in this form uh it goes on for much longer than I've shown you here and send it to dvla and they would send
back um a confirmation uh in the post so it could take uh some weeks um
and uh you also had to pay 105 which is about 1220
EUR uh and after we transformed this you can now do this online um and uh it
updates dva's records in real time so you get instant authorization of whether you can keep that license plate so you
can sell your car quickly and also because of this work um the cost of the transaction went down so it now cost Â£80
uh which is about 90 and that was passed on to the people paying for the service and this service receives 91%
user satisfaction which is pretty good for a government service and the code for this uh is on
GitHub on dva's organization um they coded in the open from the beginning so you can see um the way that that whole
project developed um so personalized license PL
is nice it's kind of fun but it's kind of um trivial so the next service I want to talk about is something that's more
serious uh which is booking a visit to see somebody in prison so Studies have shown that 45% of
prisoners lose contact with their friends and their families while they're in prison which is sad for them um but
it's also bad for society because Studies have shown that people who are not visited when they're in prison are
39% more likely to commit another crime when they're released so one of the main points of prison is Rehabilitation so uh
we don't want people to come out of prison and commit a more crime s uh you carry on we want people to be
rehabilitated so it's in the interest of society that we help make it easy for people to receive visits from their friends and
family um so the service that we worked on here um this is what this is this is
what um this is how it used to work the prisoner would initiate this process by
filling in this form uh so they'd have to give the address uh and date of birth they'd have to remember the address and
date of birth of everyone they'd like to receive a visit from from they would give this form to a prison guard who
would then send it to that person uh the the visitor would then uh send a letter back requesting a date the prison would
then send a letter back confirming the date or saying no you have to pick another date and again this could go backwards and forwards this could take
weeks this is just to arrange like a 1-hour visit to visit you know a close relative uh you know and you'd have to
do this regularly every time you wanted to visit them um the new service um allows you
sorry um I was you could also do it on the phone um but they the call centers were um like understaffed so quite often
you'd hear of people being on hold for 2 hours um or ringing several times before and not being able to get through so it
was very difficult to get a visit booked so the new service allows you to request
up to three dates online um and then uh it takes a few minutes to fill in online
and then you get a confirmation by email within 3 days usually much quicker but within three days um so it takes much
less time out of the uh out of your day to book the visit and uh the whole process takes much less time so it's
much easier um and again this service gets 85% user satisfaction which is pretty good and it also that 85%
includes the people who weren't able to get the times that they'd asked for so and they so it's quite a high rate of
satisfaction and again the code for this service is online um Ministry of Justice's GitHub
organization um and they coded in the open from the beginning so you can see exactly how the service works and how it
developed so um we worked with departments on those 25 Services we call them exam Exemplar Services um and our
role now is to support and um enable departments to do these Transformations on their own um and uh the way that
services are built um in the UK government Digital Services is by following this process um so you start
with a discovery and that's where you try and find out what the user needs are for the service um you then have an
alpha and that's where you build a couple of prototypes or just a prototype and get it in front of users to see
whether you've got the right idea about how to meet their needs um you then uh if you've got the right idea you take
one of those ideas forward into beta and that could be operational and people using it um and then if that's all well
uh the service goes live so it's worth mentioning that you might uh you don't necessarily go like that you might might
do a discovery and find out that you've got the user needs completely wrong and you have you know you don't you haven't understood your users or you might have
to do a couple of Alphas because you need to work out the right way to address those needs but it any service
that gets to live will go through all these stages and in order to pass from one stage to the next you have to pass a
service assessment which is um it needs to pass this the digital service
standard which is uh what it's 18 criteria for what makes a good
government digital service um and there's Links at the end of this talk so you can look that up if you want to look
at it but the one that's relevant to this talk is point8 make all new source code
open so that means that any digital service that's delivered by the UK government has to in order to progress
and go live make all of their new source code open so essentially this is this is a
commitment that we've made so why why have we made this commitment so there are a few reasons
why coding in the open is a good and important thing to do the first is the potential for reuse so a lot of people a
lot of departments a lot of parts of government are addressing the same problems if you code in the open then
there's a possibility that somebody can another department or another team can see the code you've used and that solves
the problem for them and they can just reuse it rather than wasting time and money by rewriting it themselves so it's
not necessarily the case the code will get reused but if you make it open you allow that possibility if it's closed
you cut that possibility off and you might think that uh you know
you know you might begin thinking this problem is completely unique um there's no way that uh anyone else will need to
use it um but you don't know that uh so you know you don't necessarily know what's going to be useful to others if
by coding in the open you allow that possibility to you know you allow that
uh to happen you allow people to see that that your code addresses their
problem and it also increases transparency ultimately we are spending public money um and this coding in the
open allows the public to see how that money is being spent so another nice thing about coding
in the open um is it's really nice to uh show what you're working on so um the
gov.uk website went through the stages I was talking about alpha beta live um and by the time time we got to live um the
service was fully operational and all that remained to do was remove the banner that said this service is in beta
so this pull request um is just removing that Banner it's essentially launching the Guk site by launching removing the
beta Banner so um this was in public so my colleague dvon raised this pull request
and people started commenting about how happy they were that this was finally
happening so a lot of these people work for GDs but many of them don't many of them are
people you know in the public
commenting so it's really nice to be able to share what you're doing
publicly um so coding in the open um is the is the default position um but there
can be some potential downsides so I'll talk about um what some of those
are um it can be difficult to get started so as
a team it can be difficult to get started as a new team that's used to coding uh in a closed Source way um I'll
talk about that a bit later but also as a new member of the team who code in the open it can be pretty intimidating if
you've come from a background where you know when you have your code reviewed the only people who see it are you and
the person reviewing the code to suddenly be in a position where literally anyone in the world could see
what comments have been made on your request before it's merged that can be quite stressful so the way we deal with that
is I mean firstly we're aware of that so nobody um nobody has to commit code on their first day if they're not
comfortable doing it we do a lot of pairing um and we have some very um clear guidelines about how to do poor
request uh code reviews um and poor request reviewing in um a constructive way so this is our poor request guidance
again that's on GitHub so you can go and have a look at that um and we've also built some kind of automated tool we've
built in automated tooling and various other ways to make the process easier and more constructive for everyone um
and this is a good plog post that's worth reading about that um so the other um potential
downside to coding in the open is um the possibility of committing something that
you shouldn't uh for example passwords or credentials so it's worth mentioning
that this could happen anyway even your your code is completely close source so there's always an opportunity for you to
leak things SEC leak you know for security to fail and for you to leak Secrets um but with coding in the open
particularly well in fact with any kind of security the important thing is to be able to recover quickly so this is in a
um environment of continuous deployment as soon as a mistake is observed we can immediately fix it and um correct it and
deploy the code immediately um within you definitely within minutes um um so
that's that's um I'm going to talk a bit more about security later um but as well
as being able to recover quickly you should also build in processes that make it harder to make mistakes so in this
case uh talking about committing passwords um you want to separate your code from your configuration uh you
shouldn't really be having passwords or credentials in your code base um and if you separate the code and configuration
then um then the the passwords are not going into the code and they're not being made
public um and so this is a reason why coding in the open for the beginning is a good idea because it forces you to do
things properly it forces you to do things like separate your code and configuration um if your first commit
doesn't you know your first commit in the open doesn't contain passwords and then you know you're in the habit of
coding in the open um there are some cases though where the code should not be committed
where we should keep the code close sourced um and I'll talk about a few of those this is a blog post where we talk
about that in more detail so one type of code um that you might want to keep close sourced uh is
um configuration maybe so this is the gov.uk puppet
repository this is also open on GitHub puppet is how we con we provision our
servers in production uh so this is the configuration for gov.uk and that is
coded in the open it wasn't coded in the open from the beginning so we had to go through a process of cleansing it and
making sure that there weren't credentials and that kind of thing and making sure that we recycled all passwords that might have um come out in
that um and this is a really good blog post that details how we did that but essentially the configuration now apart
from you know a few things private Keys Secrets is all out there and you can go and have a look at it so don't assume
that configuration also has to be kept closed source another thing that you might want to
keep close source is anything to do with security maybe so this is um this is a blog post
so this is a blog post by the gov.uk verify team go that UK verify is a service for federating Citizens sorry
confirming citizens identity to government um so that's something where security is very important because it's
people's personal data um and this project uses saml which is security
assertion markup language and uh they write they write a
lot about how they use saml um and some of their code is also open so
uh I hang on let me give you another example uh this is gchq's GitHub
organization gchq is uh government Communications Headquarters so that's
the UK's intelligence agency and they have some open source um they're not coding in the open
but they are opening some of their code so um the sort of the way we think about
security has had the context has changed um it's no longer the case that you can
just say this needs to be closed you know security says no uh and again this is a blog post that's worth reading um
but but the main point is that security uh is now it's not just about the technology it's it's holistic it's about
the users it's about the culture it's about the behavior things like separating code from configuration it's
the focus needs to be on how quickly you can recover from mistakes it used to be about how you can make it harder to make
mistakes but mistakes will happen and now the focus is about how can you reduce the the meantime to
recovery and um it's worth talking a little bit about how
security if you're sec depends on nobody knowing how it works then it's probably not very good security so a good example
is uh with say a padlock everybody knows how a padlock Works still secure what
you need to keep secret is the key so again uh you might think that you
can't code in the open with things to do with security but actually a lot of that can also be done in the open um and the third case where we say
that you might want to keep the code close sourced is uh with policy that's not yet been announced so if you you you
working commercial organizations um an analogy would be if a feature that's the marketing is not
yet been done you don't want information about that to leak before you're ready but in that case um we you code as if
you're going to release it later once the policy is announced you know make it public so that means uh no credentials
or Secrets good commit messages good documentation but you do that anyway
right so want to take a moment to say um we're
not perfect so I've given you some examples of some great stuff that we've done um the two services that I chose to
tell you about as examples of coding in the open part of the reason I chose those Services is because they did it
right they coded in the open from the beginning I can point you at their code on GitHub and you can go and see all that but there are some other services
that are also really good um that struggled um with coding in the open um
because change can be very difficult uh coming from a background where everything has to be closed Source it
can be very difficult to have that conversation and uh many of these Services started um before we'd had
those high level conversations um so for example register
to vote uh is a service which I love talking about because as part of transforming the service to make it digital we had uh legislation changed to
allow people to register individually rather than as a household um but they
uh didn't code in the open and they've started open sourcing their code but this so this is some of it but if you go
and you look at it on GitHub it's one commit and the commit is open sourcing content so that's because they didn't uh
they didn't build it uh they didn't code in the open and they didn't build it on GitHub um and again it's not like they
didn't do anything wrong the climate for them was difficult at that time and change is very difficult um that team is
working on how to um open source the rest of it um so I'm telling you that because um I don't want to stand here
and say we're amazing and we' done everything right um it's not all perfect um and also because you know to give you
courage if you want to do this in your organization you can too um it doesn't have to be perfect from the beginning if
we can make changes like this in an organization as old as the UK Civil Service then you can probably do that in
some of your organizations if you want to so I talked about the advantage of
coding in the open being um reuse uh there's a lot of people who've used our code but I'm just going to give you a
visual example of some people who've used our code so um this is gov.uk
again this is gov. NZ New Zealand's government website this is gov. Israel's Government
website and this is Lexington kentucky.gov the uh website for um Lexington's local government uh and
they've all used our gov UK front end code so it's really nice to see that uh
they they it saved them time and money okay so what I've talked about up until
now is um coding in the open but uh we make a distinction
between um coding in the open and what I would call true open source because
there are various things about our code while open that doesn't make it that means it's not open source so firstly um
we don't promise that we're going to support it we don't promise it'll work for you and your environment um that it
will work for you without all the rest of our application um it's just open um and we've not committed to
maintain it so if for example we find that there's a better way to do calculators or yeah calculators or
whatever um we'll just retire our calculator code and start working on the new code which is not very good open
source behavior um so we do have some open
source projects uh at GDs um most of those are in the infrastructure space um and this is uh
you can there are Links at the end of the talk you can see um the infrastructure open source we have I'm just going to briefly talk about one
project um which is vcloud tools uh this is a suite of ruby gems for provisioning
virtual machines in um VMware vcloud director environment um at that time our
gov UK was hosted in a VMware vcloud director environment um and these tools
um were originally coded in the open but I led a team to make them um truly open
source so I've written that up in a series of blog posts here's one of them um and basically to make them such that
they were maintained and supported and other people could use them easily uh and there were other parts of
government who are also using the same kind of Hosting environment and so they started using the tools so it was great that we were saving money across
government and we also found that there were some people in Industry using the tools so this this was really exciting
um we saw this tweet uh somebody from a Publishing Company who was using vcloud tools and um these these likes are
basically all my colleagues because we were really happy to see that somebody was using it
um so so we have done some open source not just coded in the open but um there are challenges to maintaining open
source in a work environment additional challenges to the ones I mentioned about coding in the open um I'm just going to
talk about two of them and how we address them the first is getting time to work on it so people once it's open
source people will raise issues people will raise poor requests and that doesn't always necessarily fit into the
schedule of work that you have for your team the way we dealt with that on the infrastructure team was um we had open
source Thursdays so on Thursday you could work on if there were outstanding issues or poor requests on vcloud tools
or of other of our open source which is mostly puppet modules um you could work on those um or you could work on maybe
patches for other open source software that we used and this works for our team because a lot of our work was around
those open source tools wouldn't necessarily work for a team for a different team that's just how we
addressed it um and then the second problem is uh contributors wanting to
take your project in a New Direction either one that you hadn't anticipated or maybe one that you don't
want um and this is a perennial problem in open source so I mean it's every open
source project that's successful has this problem like uh a good example is GCC the C compiler which um there was a
fork running alongside for five years so this is a problem um and uh the way we
addressed it um was basically because we knew pretty much everyone who was using it we just talked to
people uh again that wouldn't necessarily work if you don't know who's using your open source project but
that's that's what we did okay so that's where we are at the moment we have um almost everything
coded in the open and we have some open source so what's next for um GDs open
code um so I I mentioned I'm the open source lead um I've got three priorities uh they are first of all I'm going to um
try and work out what of our coded of our projects that are coded in the open would be most useful for other people
most useful to put the work in to make them actually open source or reusable uh so and not just DS like work
in other departments as well um what of their code would be useful to share
um I'm also going to be working on helping teams code in the open so I mentioned you know the register to vote
team um having difficulties um I'll be working with teams to work out like how I can break down those how we can break
down those barriers that make it hard to code in the open um and the third thing that I'm
going to be focusing on that I haven't really talked about much but is very important is um I'm going to look at
ways that we can increase our um contributions to open source software because probably like a lot of you we
depend very heavily on open source projects that maybe don't have enough support um we do contribute patches back
but I'm going to be looking at how we can um how we can do that in a more concerted useful
way so how can you get involved if you want to um few suggestions um you could
try and get if you're not already get your organizations's coding in the open um I think uh even commercial
organizations will have code that's not Central to the mission that can be open can be useful um and I hope that I've given you some
suggestions of how to address some of the problems that will come up um there's also uh some resources at the
end that might be helpful as well um you can let me know if there's any of our code gdss code or other
government's departments that you would like to use or have tried to use that would be great um because if there's something you'd like to use then I'd be
really interested in working out how we can make that easier or um you can come and work for
GDs

from the internet something about some open source than to find out what the team down the hall is working on
